revisionDesc.change: Finalized - Ready. Deleted the text here. New version of text at chr.mitt;;202.
Vote - AcceptText - Yes, make M.Chr. 202 the default. Also, record Mitteis reading, if not in the text, then as an *alt* or in the commentary.
General - The suggestion to read τῷ <ἀσχολουμένῳ> τὸ is Mitteis's, who makes the same suggestion also for P.Fay. 31 = M.Chr. 201.

Vote - DEFER - Yes, the text should default to M.Chr. 202, so dummy header will have to be added to the BGU 1 184 edition, and the text transferred to M.Chr. 202. But I agree with Mo's corrections: line 17 is right; in line 27 encode ἐὰν <:φαί̣[νηται]=PN Heidelberg Digital Papyrology Webinar 2020 (from photo)|ed|φα[ίνηται]:> <:[ἐπισ]τ̣αλῆν̣α̣ι̣=PN M. G. Elmaghrabi (from photo)|ed|[ἐπιστεί]λατε:>, and remove the |ed| tags from the end of line 27; delete the |ed| tags at the start of line 28; the restoration should be encoded <:[Σοκνοπα]ίου=PN M. G. Elmaghrabi (from photo)|ed|([Σοκνο]παί(ου)):>, which is consistent with the size of the lacuna and is a better reading (there is no pi); for lines 28-9 encode <:συν29.- [χρηματίζειν] <:[ἡμῖ]ν|reg|[ἡμεῖ]ν̣:>=PN M. G. Elmaghrabi (from photo)|ed|συν[χρη]29.- [ματίζειν ἡμεῖν]:> (but perhaps we should not restore ἡμεῖν and assume the need for regularization). Please also fix the number tags in lines 4 and 25. Contra Nick and the insertion of ἀσχολουμένῳ in line 27, cf. BGU 2 379 and P.Fay. 31. Vote conducted with the assistance of the Heidelberg Digital Papyrology Webinar, Summer 2020.

Vote - DEFER - May I suggest that BGU I 184 default into Chr.Mitt. 202, the text of ll. 27-29 be changed to what is printed in Chr.Mitt. 202, with the PN correction, i.e. ἐπιστεί]λατε ̣ => ἐπισ]τ̣αλ̣ῆ̣ν̣α̣ι̣. Add lin27 <:τῷ <ἀσχολουμένῳ> τὸ|reg|τῷ τὸ:>.
Vote - AcceptText - The suggested new readings look plausible to me. However the mark-up must be fixed, taking line-breaks into account and decide which edition to take.

Submit - BGU I 184 was re-edited in M.Chr. 202, where a correct reading (cf. photo) was offered for ll. 27-29 instead of
ἐὰν φα[ίνηται ̣ ̣ ̣ ̣] ̣ ̣ ̣ τῷ ὑπ[ο-] γραφ[έντι - ca.9 -]κ̣αινῇ οὔσῃν[ ̣] [- ca.18 -] ὡ[ς] κ[α]θήκει.
M.Chr. 202 has: ἐὰν φα[ίνηται ἐπιστεί]λατε ̣τῷ τὸ γραφ[εῖον Σοκνο]παί(ου) Νήσου συν[χρη-] [ματίζειν ἡμεῖν] ὡ[ς] κ[α]θήκει.
Instead of which I would rather read: ἐὰν φα[ίνηται ἐπιστ]αλῆναι τῷ τὸ γραφ[εῖον Σοκνοπα]ίου Νήσου συν- [χρηματίζειν ἡμεῖ]ν̣ ὡ[ς] κ[α]θήκει.

Commit - BGU I 184 was re-edited in M.Chr. 202, where a correct reading (cf. photo) was offered for ll. 27-29 instead of ἐὰν φα[ίνηται ̣ ̣ ̣ ̣] ̣ ̣ ̣ τῷ ὑπ[ο-] γραφ[έντι - ca.9 -]κ̣αινῇ οὔσῃν[ ̣] [- ca.18 -] ὡ[ς] κ[α]θήκει. M.Chr. 202 has: ἐὰν φα[ίνηται ἐπιστεί]λατε ̣τῷ τὸ γραφ[εῖον Σοκνο]παί(ου) Νήσου συν[χρη-] [ματίζειν ἡμεῖν] ὡ[ς] κ[α]θήκει. Instead of which I would rather read: ἐὰν φα[ίνηται ἐπιστ]αλῆναι τῷ τὸ γραφ[εῖον Σοκνοπα]ίου Νήσου συν- [χρηματίζειν ἡμεῖ]ν̣ ὡ[ς] κ[α]θήκει.

Finalized - Ready. ὀ̣φειλ(ῆς) κ̣α̣ί̣ seems quite likely and better than the previous reading. The epsilon followed by iota and then lambda is cramped and iota lambda makes a lot of use of the same ink stroke, but, still, the suggestions presented are, I think, an improvement.

Vote - AcceptText - l. 25: the traces of omicron following ἀπό seem certain; but for the end of the line, I would suggest something else: If one compares the average length of lines, it is somewhat surprising that in l. 25 alone three letters [καί] should be lost, although all lines are almost complete. One should not ignore the superscript letter on the last letter in the line. Thus, I suggest to read ὀ̣φειλ(ῆς) κ̣α̣ί̣. The traces after lambda match with kappa, and the superscript letter(s) could well be a cursive alpha with a iota appended.

Vote - AcceptText - Correct (ἔτους) to (ἔτει) in lin17, as requested. The readings in lins17 and 19 are clear and obviously better. In lin25 I would be inclined to interpret the ink trace after the word ἀπό as part of the omicron at the beginning of the following word and would thus suggest ὀ̣φειλῆ(ς) as the new reading.
Submit - Slight corrections in ll. 17, 19 and 25.
